text.tspan: 3DXRD Setup, viewed from above, z out of page

flowRoot.flowPara: g-vector is the scattering vector rotated into the frame of reference of the crystal.
When the sample rotations are zero g = k. Otherwise:
k = Ra Rb Rc [...] Rn g
eg: g is rotated by a series of matrices to give k which fulfills the diffraction condition, which is
Last line substituted for sinθ. This equation is relating the length of the scattering vector to the angle the planes make with the incident beam.
3DXRD has a single vertical rotation axis, Ω which rotates in an anti-clockwise sense when viewed from above (eg it is a right handed rotation around z).
Finding the right angle to get a diffraction spot for an arbitrary rotation:
Identify the rotation axis/ angle which is being moved as R. Any post rotations are applied to g.
k = [Ra Rb Rc] [R] [Rd Re Rf] g
The inverse of the pre-rotations are applied to the incident beam, So, and then we take the dot product of the rotated So and k. This remains numerically as k.So = |g||g|/2.
The component of gr along the rotation axis is invarient under rotation. Components perpendicular to the axis, a, are computed as
a1 = a x g ; a2 = a1 x a ; a3 = g - a2.
Our rotated vector is then given by:
a1sinφ + a2cosφ + a3; where φ is the rotation angle
A dot product of this with the rotated incident beam allows us to solve for φ.
All quantities are now scalars and we solve using the identity:
